scenes.location: RUSTIC STUDIO OF AN ARTISAN. DAY 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of shots. Blue sky through shabby windows. Run down walls. A paint splashed pine floor.    Tens of p brushes soaking in stained jars. An artisan's hands - weather-worn, swirling a paint brush in dirty water that sways at the bottom of one of the jar A canvas - the sketched face of a woman - blonde, blue ey as the artisan strokes paint into her features - a poster girl for 18th century portraiture. (We will later recognise her as ELIZABETH MURRAY)

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. DOCKS/SLUM ROOM. ENGLAND
dialogues.text: A swallow cuts across a red tinged sky.   SOUND of footst trudging through mud. EXTREME CLOSE UP: a small figure being dressed by someone a shoulder, an arm, little hands. We do not see a face. CLOSE: heavy naval boots move at sombre pace through slum Against a stone floor, a child's feet are laced into boot A starving dog barks , darts between tradesmen, sailors. Hold this image as Handel comes to an END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CHILD'S POV as the door opens. We see a gentleman in ceremonial naval dress - CAPTAIN SIR JOHN LINDSAY, aristocratic, handsome...alarmed at the sight before him. His eyes close with some sad, internal pain and as they r open...We see what he sees... A fragile girl...around six years old stands in shabby surroundings. Her terrified eyes stare back, leaving LINDSAY at a loss. He takes in her features - delicate with a full mouth that underlines her ethnicity. She is DIDO ELIZABETH BELLE...part black, part white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speaks quietly- words almost as fragile as she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello little girl...Little Dido. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am your father. Silence. Then a tear rises to the surface and as her confused tears spill, so too do LINDSAY'S. His POV: a POOR BLACK WOMAN oversees DIDO from afar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re. Dido)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How lovely she is. So much of her mother. (his eyes sting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried...but how...how could I separate a mother from her child? (he restrains tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now nature has deprived me of such a dilemma. He composes himself - feeling futile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you..for taking her. He reaches into his pocket, holds out money to the woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may leave us. The WOMAN hesitates, scurries to DIDO, placing her lips t the child's head in a prolonged kiss. Then she is gone. DIDO is left frightened and stunned!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not be afraid sweet thing. I am to take you to a good life. The life you were born to. He takes out a cube of chocolate, shows it to her. She is reluctant. He takes a bite - delicious! DIDO moves forward. He puts the chocolate in her hand. She tastes it. Sweet cocoa and sugar..and now her tiny mouth is filled. It makes LINDSAY laugh out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A driver, HARRY - seated at a fine carriage. As HARRY becomes alarmed - from his POV LINDSAY moves towards us - the mulatto child in arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence, except bird song - the splendor of the English countryside - A neoclassical estate stretches before us. The figure of a LITTLE GIRL running across the lawns - he giggle fills the air, her outline faded by the sun. At French doors to the nursery, a furious greying woman - LADY MARY MURRAY (40s), waves a wooden spoon and yells...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth Murray, bring yourself back here this very moment! The child crashes to the grass in fits of laughter. She i no more than 6 years old - Hair the colour of bleached ha and delicate pale skin. She rolls on to her back, squinting at the sunlight as... The SOUND of horse and carriage at the front of the house ELIZABETH bolts upright. Her POV: As CAPTAIN SIR JOHN LINDSAY guides DIDO from the carriage. WIMBRIDGE, the butler, steps out to receive them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY MANSFIELD (40s), the years have been kind. She is beautiful, regal - stares ahead in shock... LORD MANSFIELD (50's) - a majestic man, white wigged and low brows, is incandescent, his sister, LADY MARY, frozen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in God's name have you done!! Their POV - LINDSAY and little DIDO stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She...she is black. LINDSAY is pained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is my blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she IS black!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A detail you chose NOT to share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle? You assured me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fury) Captain Sir John Lindsay, do you find me a fool? She is a MULATTO! LORD MANSFIELD'S blood boils, he rages towards LINDSAY. L MANSFIELD restrains him. LINDSAY is red with humiliation. CAPTAIN SIR JOHN LINDSAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no wife to take her...In a few hours I am to captain a voyage to the Indies on a longitude experiment. (strained) From there, who knows!!! It is not in my gift to question the King and his Royal Navy. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep in mind my position..? My reputation...? CAPTAIN SIR JOHN LINDSAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir... LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then have some sense of propriety boy...and understand what you are asking. LINDSAY lowers his voice, shielding DIDO. SIR JOHN LINDSAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mother is dead! My wishes may not be orthodox but they ARE necessary! LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we raise her...? SIR JOHN LINDSAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you, uncle...love her - as I would, were I here. (sadly) And ensure that she is in receipt of all that is due to her as a child of mine. LADY MARY gasps, under... LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is simply impossible. SIR JOHN LINDSAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is right can never be impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His firm gaze holds his aunt and uncle to account. A long beat. LADY MANSFIELD stands conflicted. LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has she been named? SIR JOHN LINDSAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is Belle...after her mother. Dido Elizabeth Belle...Lindsay. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes your name? SIR JOHN LINDSAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not ashamed. LINDSAY stands his ground. LADY MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cannot have another Elizabeth in the household. LADY MANSFIELD regards the child, then looks to her husband, gravely. He turns his back - aggrieved. LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We...we will call her Dido. (off Lindsay's nod) Good Lord, she is thin. Mary, find her something to eat. LORD MANSFIELD storms from the room. LADY MANSFIELD follows. LINDSAY kneels, choked with emotion. SIR JOHN LINDSAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Belle - sweet child... (weak smile) My wish is to keep you...keep you with me...but a ship...it is no place for one so precious as you. (pause) In these walls, yours will be a life equal to my blood. A beat. Through eyes that brim...he catches his breath. LADY MARY is both stunned and moved - she has to turn awa SIR JOHN LINDSAY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not understand in this moment, but hold this in your heart...you are loved...Just as I loved your mother. A tear spills and DIDO's little fingers come up to wipe i from his cheek. He presses his lips to her hand, sobbing moment, and then he is gone - to stay any longer would be too much to bare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ELIZABETH seated at the grand staircase as LADY MARY a DIDO emerge. Like ELIZABETH, DIDO is now freshly dressed rich silks, an adorable sight as they move through corrid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you...a nee-gro? ELIZABETH makes her way across...taking her aunt's hand a all three walk. DIDO is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you what they call `a negro?' I heard them talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Questions, questions, Elizabeth! Tis a most irritating trait you and your father share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa M?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No your blood papaa. Sir David Murray. You should not insist on always speaking your mind, you know. You will end up an old maid with only your own company for entertainment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you, Aunt Mary? That is what the maids say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little.... ELIZABETH takes off. LADY MARY rushes after her. DIDO is left alone - through the doorway of the gallery, portrait of LINDSAY stares at her. She gazes at it. LORD MANSFIELD approaches, arrested at the sight of DIDO, newly tidied. He follows her gaze to LINDSAY'S image. The sight affects him, unexpectedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sir John Lindsay. (off her reaction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recognise him? She nods. A beat as conflict fills him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you see here...? This..this is your grandfather, Sir Alexander Lindsay of Evelick. DIDO examines the painting. LORD MANSFIELD watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am here too....do you see? Her eyes search the long line of her aristocratic heritag until her gaze settles. He chuckles, reluctantly charmed she points to his likeness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...I am William Murray, First Earl of Mansfield. A beat as he looks to her, affected by this little person Gently, he leads her to a final portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now...do you see this man? He is my nephew...do you understand...? (off Dido's nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...your uncle - Sir David Murray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth's papa. He pauses

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a sharp little one. He is The Seventh Viscount Stormont... (beat. Almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to inherit everything that we are standing on when I am gone. She nods, bites her lip - that much has gone over her head...he can see. He closes his eyes. The enormity of th new responsibility weighing heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD's POV: through window - The lawns. ELIZABE gently takes DIDO'S hand in hers, leads her off to run between the trees. As their delighted screams filter... LADY MANSFIELD enters - observes LORD Mansfield, a moment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Born on English soil?

dialogues.speaker: LORD MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: Indeed. He discovered her mother aboard a captured Spanish slave ship. He was charged with conveying it back to these shores, he tells me.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: Evidently he had some...`feeling' for the woman.

dialogues.speaker: LORD MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: (dry) And there I was believing it was sheer lack of `self control'. (scathing) He has been at sea, six years. All of this child's life!

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: Well, he clearly saw to their wellbeing. The child is not altogether uncivilized. (she breathes deeply) So...now we have two nieces in our guardianship.

dialogues.speaker: LORD MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: (reticent) Elizabeth was much in need of a companion.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: And that is what we shall say when questions are asked of us?

dialogues.speaker: LORD MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: We shall say that in accordance with her birthright, she is entitled to live beneath this roof. (with irony) Such...is the nature of `order'.

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: And where in this `order' should her colour be placed? Below or above her Murray bloodline? (off his silence) May she dine with us?

dialogues.speaker: LORD MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: She may...(pause)...NOT...in company. We cannot escape society's confines on etiquette

dialogues.speaker: LADY MANSFIELD
dialogues.text: Marriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head at the complexity of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible. Any match her..'other origins' may attract would surely disgrace her and the family rank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when we are no longer here? No husband - who will take care of her? He rubs his eyebrows, perturbed, turns back to the lawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A view across the idyllic estate. SOUNDS of children's shrieks have become adult.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION
dialogues.text: A twenty year old DIDO darts between trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bette! No...no surprises Bette! ELIZABETH, also twenty now, suddenly jumps from behind th willows, causing DIDO to wail hysterically. LADY MARY stands at the doorway of the old nursery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrieking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls! Will you refrain from shrieking like the...bless-ed French! The girls race towards the house. ELIZABETH'S blonde colouring remains, whilst DIDO'S looks have become dramatic - her dark hair, thick and long, wra in a bun, and black lashes that frame her dark eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church bells - parishioners make their way into the beautiful sixteenth century chapel, in lush green fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEREND DAVINIER, white wigged, stands at the pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth. So saith Christ the Lord. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen. A FLAME as a YOUNG MAN lights a candle by the altar. He s choir-like, the word `amen' rather than simply saying it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hymn no. 76. ON the MANSFIELDS as the congregation begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN stands collecting bibles as the congregatio file out. DIDO hands him hers. He is chaotically handsome with deeply set, expressive ey that lock with hers for a moment, stirring her. Then his gaze moves suddenly to LORD MANSFIELD - intense, as he watches him drift from the church, the family in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pure, lush, green. The Mansfield carriage on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD and LADY MANSFIELD sit together, ELIZABETH beside them. DIDO and LADY MARY ride backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have reason to speak with you alone, Dido. DIDO is quietly alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I wronged you, Papaa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have done no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD is grave.    DIDO stands before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not past experience in the ways of breaking grave news to you. He hands her a letter and she reads. A beat, as the news resonates through her, silently. Her pained gaze slowly rises to meet LORD MANSFIELD'S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, shock)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I should one day have the opportunity to make his better acquaintance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two thousand pounds a year? ELIZABETH sits at the edge of the bed in day clothes. DID nods, her back to us as she stares out through the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you are an heiress! He has left you your fortune!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. DIDO and ELIZABETH lie in separate beds. Only a shaft of moonlight illuminates their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have loved you, Dido.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did not know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's new wife wishes him to leave me not a thing, and he obliges her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it is her cruelty you should lament, Bette, not his stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he might have loved me more if Mamaa had not died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pained)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I think love must be a very complicated thing. ELIZABETH lifts her head to look across at DIDO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido - with such a dowry you may marry into any good family you wish. OFF DIDO as she stares at the ceiling, daunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft sunlight filters. LADY MARY sits engrossed in her needle-work. The two girls persevere with theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall receive visitors for dinner. The two girls exchange a glance and whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visitors? Who ever bothers to visit us here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or leave... except the dead! ELIZABETH'S titters escape. LADY MARY looks up, abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, Dido?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beds...Aunt Mary. We should prepare some extra beds... in case our visitors are to stay... She trails off - LADY MARY raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May we wear the new silks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do your hair, Bette. Oh say we may wear them, Aunt Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not be dining with us, Dido. The room falls silent and the girls' energy is killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes of course. But I may join after dinner, may I not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Such are the rules, and you know them well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blaze of rhododendron, azaleas. DIDO strolls with LORD MANSFIELD, along Kenwood's lake, orange sunlight glistens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a most disagreeable... hideous, old maid - I hate her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not! She is only managing the dictates of the household

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa...how...how may I be too high in rank to dine with the servants and too low to dine with my family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner with guests is a formal proceeding, Dido - we simply cannot impose the disregard of those formalities upon visitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...Papaa, am I not..'wealthy', now...an heiress? Surely that changes matters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear...I wish it were so simple. Finances may go some way - but Society has a habit of disregarding even one of their own, when opportunity provides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course...(trailing off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUT after dinner...when formality is of less consequence...well your presence can raise no defendable objections. (off her sadness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido, you know the rules of propriety. Far better than Elizabeth, if I am frank. His loving gaze elicits a smile from her, weary. Propriet is everything, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you wish, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY MANSFIELD sits in the shade - a maid prepares a seat for LADY MARY, as DIDO heads for the house, pensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido!... ELIZABETH emerges from the house, breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. I have been searching for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dido)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a wretched countenance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She deplores my authority. What am I in this household, if not the `observer of rules'?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would rather dine with Dido! She links arms with DIDO in solidarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a great pity LADY MANSFIELD and LADY MARY feign nonchalance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our young gentlemen guests shall miss you, Elizabeth. Both girls' eyes widen - DIDO's with disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young gentlemen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good connections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And most agreeable by all accounts! ELIZABETH'S mouth falls open. LADY MARY leans toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close your mouth and understand: There shall be no discussions tonight in any languages other than English! No whisperings in gentlemen's ears - not in Latin, Italian...and certainly not French! OFF ELIZABETH'S mischief and Dido sunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candles sprinkle a delicate light. An imposing dining tab stretches before us, laden with exquisite foods.   LADY ASHFORD 40's - a pale porcelain skinned woman, sits with her sons - JAMES (25) and OLIVER (22). She is beautiful a both have inherited her striking looks. ELIZABETH whispers in JAMES' ear. LADY MARY glares!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What excellent French! Though I have not an idea of what you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said...`Your hands have the suggestion of a sensitive man'. She wrinkles her nose, minxish. Across the table...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must say, the entire country barely breathes awaiting your judgement on this appeal. Terrified you shall destroy England, no doubt. I know Lord A is. He does wonder though, what can be taking you...so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mild condescension)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The law, Lady Ashford. It is to be interpreted - not merely administered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband of all people knows this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother is not a man of rash instinct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For that we are all grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a lot of fuss over dead cargo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a fuss over the bread and butter of a great many in these isles. A great many, Lady Ashford. OFF LORD MANSFIELD'S distaste....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows glint with candlelight, DIDO sits at a bench alone. Laughter from the house carries in the breeze. A rustle in the branches behind her. She stands, startled A beat, then she turns on her heels and sprints - fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathless, DIDO races inside as WIMBRIDGE appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wimbridge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are poachers wandering...! The sound of the echoing doorbell, jolting DIDO. Her eyes dart to the door. WIMBRIDGE hesitates, then answers. A YOUNG MAN stands, damp brow, and as breathless as DIDO. We recognise him as the YOUNG MAN seen earlier in the church. He is JOHN DAVINIER, son of REVEREND DAVINIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening to you. I am John Davinier, I..I believe I may have disturbed a lady of this house... He sets eyes on DIDO, peering from the great staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah...she is there. (calling out to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please forgive me...though you barely gave me a chance... DIDO turns her back, horrified. How dare he address her without formal introduction?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I do not believe we have been introduced! JOHN takes hold of himself, half mortified, half irritate JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. I...I... (to Wimbridge, feeling foolish) Please inform the lady of my apologies for startling her. I took advantage of the back fields, by way of a short-cut to deliver this to Lord Mansfield... from my father. WIMBRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? He hands WIMBRIDGE an envelope. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Davinier. WIMBRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, sir. I will see that he gets it immediately... DIDO can't help but interfere. She calls over her shoulde DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shall not interrupt him at dinner, Wimbridge! WIMBRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately - after dinner, sir. JOHN resists rolling his eyes - ghastly female! JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course...thank you. He backs away. DIDO still shows him nothing but her back. JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wimbridge, awkward) Good night. WIMBRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, sir. He moves off, and is gone as DIDO finally turns, stares a the closed door, flushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single figure - at the farthest end of the crimson drawing room...DIDO'S heart skips a beat at the SOUND of the approaching dinner party...Suddenly the doors open ...DIDO stands quickly - nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido...my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to her sons)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord - the negro! She really is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly disturbed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capital!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hadn't expected her to look so...black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamaa, did you not listen to the rumours when you were spreading them? DIDO curtseys respectfully to LORD MANSFIELD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I present to you the second of my nieces - Miss Dido Lindsay. DIDO curtseys. LADY ASHFORD nods graciously. OLIVER bows has to nudge his troubled brother do the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure, Miss Lindsay. She curtseys once again, then moves to sit with ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto - re. James)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the eldest - to inherit the entire Ashford fortune. He is also to inherit from his uncle - a healthy man, who shows little sign of departure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Ashford herself. She seems rather despondent at her brother's robust constitution. JAMES catches DIDO'S soft brown eyes resting on him. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has much to recommend him. And a second fortune in life should please any wife. ELIZABETH clocks the gaze between DIDO and JAMES. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido! You are not to be a coquette with him! You already have your fortune! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting I now condescend to a gentleman without means, Bette?! What should good society think of us! OLIVER moves to his brother, follows his gaze to DIDO. OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is intriguing, is she not? JAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find her repulsive. OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose she is...if you find a most rare and exotic flower so. She is quite something to behold. ON DIDO as she falters under the brothers' stares. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered, to DIDO) Good Lord! They are appraising me! ELIZABETH composes herself. JAMES' eyes remain on DIDO, swallowing hard at her undeniable beauty. JAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One does not make a wife of the rare and exotic, Oliver. One samples it on the cotton fields of the Indies... OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far, when it is right at my door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Then finds a pure ENGLISH rose to decorate one's home. OLIVER smiles. OFF both men - trained on DIDO. 26   INT. KENWOOD HOUSE. DRAWING ROOM - NIGHT 4. ELIZABETH is at the pianoforte. She sings, plays hard, fo JAMES' attention, gazing up at him as he stands beside he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she `OUT'??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any day now. LADY ASHFORD raises an amused eyebrow - precocious creatu OLIVER offers DIDO a discreet smile, as she sits beside LORD MANSFIELD. His mother quietly moves across to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will refrain from any intercourse with the negress. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord and Lady Mansfield may find it fascinating to have a Lady Mulatto running around their household, but I will not have one running around mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is an heiress. A seamless change of heart for LADY ASHFORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although exceptions can be made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is said that her father left her a rather vast fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean to say, if that is your inclination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is rather soft on the eye - I have thought no further Mamaa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY ASHFORD stares across at DIDO. LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From where did you receive your information? OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her sister-cousin has a rather fast tongue. ON LADY ASHFORD as she studies DIDO. ELIZABETH finishes, amid a smattering of polite applause led by JAMES. OLIVER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what of you Miss Lindsay? Are we to hear you play tonight? DIDO looks up to find OLIVER smiling across at her. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (deferring to her father) Papaa...? LORD MANSFIELD hesitates. DIDO is embarrassed. OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh do not be selfish with your good fortune, m'lord! A beat...then put on the spot, LORD MANSFIELD caves, throwing up his hands, helplessly. DIDO is tentative, ELIZABETH less pleased. LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will be most interesting! DIDO moves to the pianoforte settles her fingers on the keys. A beat, then Handel's Suite No.9 fills the room. LORD MANSFIELD closes his eyes, irritated with himself. LADY MARY whispers to LADY MANSFIELD. LADY MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has never played in company! LADY MANSFIELD is silent - stiff with anxiety. DIDO is raising a beautiful and fluent sound - as skillfu as the most gifted of Georgian young ladies. LORD MANSFIELD'S eyes spring open - sees all held hostage OLIVER moves forward, utterly fascinated. Relief floods LADY MANSFIELD - she sighs with pride as LA MARY lends LADY ASHFORD a smug look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conceding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is...most accomplished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with deep satisfaction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hers was a most diligent governess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Echoing footsteps. LORD and LADY MANSFIELD move toward their rooms, each with a lamp to light their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The liberty of asking her to play! And when he can have no better intentions towards her. She stops in her tracks briefly, suddenly unsure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can he?? They round a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...His family name will, no doubt, entice her to take him seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must not delude herself. Such decisions are not hers to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then spell it out to her! Before she renders herself...sport to some `gent' of cruel promises!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has no reason. Hers is an inheritance that renders her free of the usual inducements to marry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that, at least, is true, (burdened, grave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, it is Elizabeth who needs to secure her bread and butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feminine feet move along the corridor.   REVEAL DIDO maki her way to LORD MANSFIELD'S study. Her POV: through the doorway to the studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An UNFAMILIAR FACE mixing paints, engrossed. His weather- worn hands are recognisable from the opening credits. His stare meets DIDO's, calmly moved by her beauty as she stands, frozen - her full lips parted in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH stands at the mirror - a maid dressing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A portrait? Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...Aunt Mary has confirmed it. DIDO sits, light headed, anxiety running through her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord. How...truly wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (becoming exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what, Dido?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO hurls herself into the room, utterly panicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa...should he not have wished to SEE me before deciding? She throws her hands up woefully, and finds another face staring back at her - It is JOHN DAVINIER. He regards her from a huge law book. She stands mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lord M)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry...I did not know you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier, I believe you have already had the pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In...some way - yes. (to DIDO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay. She curtseys, brief and stiff - a smile to match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decide what? She is hesitant now, awkward in JOHN'S presence. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he should...should WANT to paint me! LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is to be paid a fortune. What is there to decide? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido, you are to simply sit still. Not a challenging task! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious) Next...next to Elizabeth...? LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you always are - right beside one another. DIDO's chest heaves with distress. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should...should not any lady be flattered to be such a subject? His tone is impatient, irritating her. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should any male know the ways of a lady when he has not even mastered the ways of a gentleman? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite! Though one should be forgiven for thinking he was in the presence of a lady - when she is, in fact, still a juvenile! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa, may we do this in private! LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, no! You may return the books to the library. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD casts her a stare and she is silenced. DIDO begins collecting giant hardbacks, exasperated. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon her husband's death a widow may receive.... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...her marriage portion and inheritance at once. She has forty days to leave her husband's home... LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hummm... (contemplation) Yours are grand ambitions. JOHN says nothing - swallows hard. DIDO steals a glance. LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the purpose of the law in your eyes, Mr Davinier? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To... to provide certainty where there might otherwise be none. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Example. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Zong ship and those drowned. LORD MANSFIELD stiffens. He looks uncomfortably at DIDO piling books. JOHN'S eyes follow. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is one of the few trades acceptable to a gentleman. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am no member of the nobility - I have little, but...where my father relies on the bible, I...I wish to rely on the law courts. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aspire to the judiciary? LORD MANSFIELD laughs at him. DIDO stares at the ground - cringing on JOHN'S behalf. John asserts himself. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day...yes...m'lord. I wish to make the laws not only administer them - for that...that is how I may truly change this world. I mean to say, make it... a better place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. His words force DIDO to look up, affected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noble if not pompous! A country lawyer, you may make - perhaps! If you pay every regard to what you are taught - but you have neither the rank nor finances for any more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentative)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may, m'lord - neither did you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...as a fourth son, you had rank but not the income to pay for your qualification to the Inns. DIDO's wide eyes take in JOHN, astonished by his chuzpah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without the sponsorship of Lord Foley and William Hamilton...the English courts may not have benefited from your brilliance - and the title, Lord Chief Justice could not be yours today...M'lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe you are worthy of such considerations? Such are your capabilities?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I do not know, M'lord. I have not yet been afforded those considerations...but I know a country life does not suit me. LORD MANSFIELD's gaze is trained on JOHN. DIDO has finish gathering the books and is quietly slipping from the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Reverend has requested I take his son into my tutorage, Dido. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? DIDO freezes, in the doorway - all eyes locked on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO moves along the hallway, lined with enormous artists interpretations, communicating a certain lifestyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slows, caught by one of the paintings - an English ro stares out, as a black domestic submissively fastens a priceless bracelet around her lady-master's wrist. DIDO's POV: CLOSE on the domestic. Suddenly... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for your gracious support. DIDO jumps - finds JOHN standing beside her. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I neither spoke for or against you - since neither is my place. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence speaks volumes. Elizabeth approaches, calls out, as she curtseys. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa's new student. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier, my cousin, Elizabeth. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to John) Papaa has never taken a pupil, you realise? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone to keep you company while you take Papaa's dictation, Dido. (to John) Truth is, there have been more of your sex at Kenwood this week, than I've previously seen in all my entire life! DIDO flushes. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopefully we have not disappointed! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary! She raises a minxish eyebrow and moves off. Awkward silen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier, what...what is the importance of the Zong... why is the case before Papaa's court, the supreme court...? He searches her, taken aback.   Why is she asking him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (he struggles, tentative) It is a cargo ship. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I am aware of that. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A human-cargo ship. DIDO hesitates, tentative. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. You said those who were drowned. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It lost most of its slaves before arriving at its destination. (hesitant) Drowned - by the crew on the captain's order. JOHN watches as DIDO falters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...why? The SOUND of the MANSFIELDS gathering with the ASHFORDS. maid approaches hurrying about her duties. MAID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss, your supper is served now in the ladies' parlour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. JOHN hesitates, struck with confusion at the maid's words DIDO becomes awkward. LADY MANSFIELD emerges, disappearin into the dining room. LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier, will you be joining us for dinner? JOHN's eyes dart to DIDO - sees her unease. It pierces hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I..er...I thank you, Madam, but I am promised to the company of my aunt this evening. She has recently moved to the cottage at Belsize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course - as you wish. She moves off, and DIDO and JOHN are left in tense silenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Permit me to ask, why you do not dine with your family - ever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me...but twice now I have seen...I have seen you separated from the gathering. DIDO's cheeks begin to burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am confounded. DIDO snaps, her shame over-spilling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And well you might be - when the son of clergy is permitted to the table before a lady of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a reminder of my place, Miss Lindsay? She holds back frustrated tears, pained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's a statement of mine! Both of them are smarting. JOHN moves off, stung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO steps into the room, expressionless. She sits on the chaise longue, allows her gaze to settle on her reflectio Something terrible resonates through her - some awful thought or feeling, that leaves her breathless with emotion. And then her fingers come up to the skin on her chest...and she begins to pinch and pull with self-hatred rubbing the heel of her palm across her cheek, her forehead, as her face crumples and she begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New day. LORD MANSFIELD and JOHN ride through Kenwood's lands on horseback, slowing under the shade of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he pats his animal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is much speculation on your decision. Anticipation seems to be turning to panic, m'lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot disagree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred and thirty two drowned on route from Africa to the West Indies. Your ruling could bring the slave trade to its knees - entirely destroy an economic foundation of these lands. (off Mansfield)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that pressure not maddening, m'lord? LORD MANSFIELD reigns in his horse. He quotes in Latin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justitia fiat, ruat coelum, Mr Davinier - Let justice be done, though the heavens may fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The insurance claim states, the slaves were thrown overboard for the safety of the ship - that there wasn't sufficient water for the cargo and crew to survive the rest of the voyage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, if I am correct, the case hangs on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...IT HANGS on `Absolute necessity'. If the cargo was spoiled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cargo? LORD MANSFIELD adjusts his language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the killing of the..'negros' was truly `necessary' in order to save the ship - as the captain contends. A difficult silence.   JOHN is careful, but sceptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...is that where it hinges? LORD MANSFIELD does not welcome the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship's journey was thwarted by impossible weather conditions - what should have been weeks became months! What once appeared enough water, may not have been!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sensible of this, m'lord...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then do you know what a hundred thirsty slaves are capable of? I can tell you no man happily disposes of his cargo, even in the face of rebellion! (Off John's silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now tell me - were you to dock at port with barely a piece of merchandise left to trade - what would you do?   Swallow financial ruin - or claim your due from the insurers. John is conflicted - to speak up, or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With due respect... I should question, whether 'human' life should have been insurable as cargo - at all. The air turns cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY MARY clips flowers from a bush of sunset pink Dahlia DIDO holds a basket, collecting them. LADY MANSFIELD and ELIZABETH stroll beneath parasols. LORD MANSFIELD and JOHN can be seen approaching the stabl on horseback - JOHN trailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gentleman rather like him once paid me much interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter of fact.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, Mary? DIDO lays each Dahlia carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not look at me like that! It was my Mamaa who intervened. I thought he had a very great sense of duty. Overly kind at times but... LADY MANSFIELD watches as though she knows the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...what, Aunt Mary? LADY MARY hesitates and LADY MANSFIELD cuts in, saving he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE is engaged, you know? DIDO follows her gaze to JOHN, as he climbs from the hors hands it to a STABLEMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engaged!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Beresford's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage-maker! He might have set his sights a little higher! AS JOHN marches toward the back entrance of the house. He nods to the ladies. A self-conscious beat between he and DIDO, her back to him - as he disappears inside. OFF her reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: the soft curls around DIDO'S hairline, a single eye, her nose, cheek. HOLD on her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON the painter's canvas...a sketch emerging - he brings DIDO'S mouth to life. We see an outline of ELIZABETH with some detail, already been created. REVEAL ELIZABETH beside DIDO. As her hand slides over to DIDO'S and she squeezes it tight. ON their clasped hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the window, Miss Lindsay DIDO favours the window a little more...Soft sunlight pou onto her skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN moves through corridors - hat under his arm. ELIZABE emerges from the studio, drawing his attention to... Through a half open doorway, his POV: DIDO sits on stool before ZOFFANY. The sight draws JOHN to a halt. He attempts to move off - but cant! He observes DIDO quietly. She is somehow tranquil under Zoffany's gaze. A beat before her eyes fall on JOHN'S outline in the doorway - his stare, penetrating and compelling. ON ZOFFANY - he follows DIDO'S gaze to JOHN. Then he sketches madly, filling in DIDO'S eyes in great detail. ON JOHN, embarrassed - he moves away quickly.   DIDO is affected. She jumps up! Goes after him! As ELIZABETH'S eyes follow, uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... She is upon him in the CORRIDOR! They stand silent, awkwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I was curious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a task - to sit for so many                       * hours...(beat)... Congratulations! I learned of your..your match..yesterday.                            *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He falters slightly, swallows hard - not all is well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes hone in on a pamphlet under his arm. JOHN shifts uneasy at what it shows - the last few letters of THE ZON can be seen, and LORD MANSFIELD depicted with large butt. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appear the only one to have just learned of this affair? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps yours is a life less concerned with such matters. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you judge me so? He studies her. She is tentative. DIDO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a fact that I have contemplated on the matter for many hours, and I...I do not think the slaves could have been drowned in the way you say. ON his disbelief - irritation slowly turns to dawning. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you at utter disconnect from everything?! He searches her, making her feel very small and ashamed. he moves off, she stares after him, distressed. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier...please. Tell me. Tell me what you know! He stops, stares back at her.   What to do? DIDO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnest) Do not render me your amusement. He traces her vulnerability. It roots him. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only tell you what I believe. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to understand) And what...what is that? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slaves were intentionally drowned, that is not in question. Chained! Thrown into the waters - chained together as one. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were diseased - worth more as dead insured merchandise, than as alive spoiled goods. (stark)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain hoped it would `pay' to kill them. ON DIDO as colour drains from her face.   Nausea rises... His eyes try to read hers, becoming sensitive. As he move back towards her. She struggles to take it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay....?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the insurers are appealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They are challenging the decision of the lower court - refusing to pay for murdered slaves. Her eyes sting. JOHN can see she is having difficulty - h touches her hand absentmindedly, startling her, but their eyes remain locked. She attempts, weakly, to return self- possession. Then almost a whisper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. That is, thank you for telling me what nobody else has! She turns, walks away.    ON DIDO, as her pace quickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DIDO, urgently rifling through files, shelves - chaoti She moves to a desk, pulls open drawers - REVEAL volumes and volumes of news pamphlets. A set of them bound, LORD MANSFIELD'S wax seal hanging from the cord. She unties th cord, wax seal all over her hands. She fingers her way through the pile - legal headlines...all referring to Lor Mansfield. She stops dead... POV - pamphlet cover...image of LORD MANSFIELD, drooping bottom lip touching the ground - foolish and dithering, whilst beside him a `Negro' slave wields a judge's' gavel A headline - `Slave Cargo Deliberately Drowned to save sh - Mansfield Dithers on Zong Insurance'. DIDO stares hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs her fingers across the caricature, pained - then moves urgently to the next pamphlet, and the next... More MANSFIELD caricatures - a big nose, fat lips, all wi Zong headlines:'Mansfield to Rule on "Disposable Slaves" The library door suddenly opens, jolting DIDO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are! DIDO is frozen, says nothing. ELIZABETH stares from the doorway - why does DIDO look so strange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are requested. You - drawing room. I, relegated to the ladies' Palour! She disappears leaving DIDO bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH stands before LADY MANSFIELD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are to attend London for the Season. ELIZABETH'S eyes are wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO mirrors ELIZABETH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are to finally `come out'?? LORD MANSFIELD stares back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clarifying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is to come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido is not. ELIZABETH'S face falls. 41   INT. KENWOOD HOUSE. DRAWING ROOM - CONTINUOUS. DAY. LORD MANSFIELD stares solemnly at DIDO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand the ways of this world for a female, Dido. Elizabeth has no income. When all this is gone to her father, I have nothing to leave her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are to meet as many gentlemen as possible, before we make the match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido, you are well taken care of - Of this, you are well aware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gentleman of good breeding is unlikely to form any serious attachment to Dido, and a man without, will lower her position in society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she is not merely my cousin, Mamaa, she is my sister. I cannot attend London without her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO'S gaze is pained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may attend London together to keep Elizabeth company and save the pain of a few weeks separation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY MANSFIELD shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord knows I will need you both to keep each other out of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not to be denied, Dido. He looks down. DIDO'S eyes follow to a large bunch of key

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the keys to the house. They have hung at the waist of your aunt for the last thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I am not Lady Mary. I am not an unwanted maid! LORD MANSFIELD feels no choice but to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Mary is too old to continue in charge of the house. He places the keys in her hand and closes her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may assume her duties on your return. A most respectable position for an unmarried Mansfield Lady. She stares at him, disbelieving, bereft...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are...are you punishing me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punishing you!! Dido, you are most cherished. Most loved. Why ...why would you say such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to find courage to speak. LORD MANSFIELD waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because ... She swallows hard...loses courage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because what? A moment. He looks down, sees the bright red wax from his seal on her fingers. ON his slow dawning. Ominous beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH steps from the ladies' parlour - DIDO from the drawing room, winded with emotion. As they fall into each other's arms, weeping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, Dido. So very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD stands alone restraining his tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD's eyes are wild. JOHN stands before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told her they were wantonly drowned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they were! Those slaves were diseased - some were already dying - yes. But it was essential they die ON the journey or they would not come under insurance consideration! Neither too, if they had expired of their diseases - That is why they were killed - this we all know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have entered my home and utterly taken advantage of the confidential matters afforded you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These `matters' have been for public consumption for months. Miss Lindsay is no child...no.. fool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incandescent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her precious care is in my hands and I will decide when she is ready for such realities. Not the son of a vicar! A vicar who, incidently purchased his living from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall gather my belongings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do so! LORD MANSFIELD turns his back on JOHN to glare at the law JOHN calmly collects his books, jacket, hat. He hesitates

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Lordship, a question? LORD MANSFIELD swings round ready to bite..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT, Mr Davinier!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the mere son of a vicar - I wonder whether the value you extend to your very precious mulatto niece - well I wonder if it amounts to MORE...or LESS than the thirty pounds insurance the traders are asking for each life they murdered? ON LORD MANSFIELD'S cold stare.   He swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, M'lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier. JOHN stops, turns to LORD MANSFIELD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A word to the wise. Find yourself in her vicinity again, and you will rue the day you cast eyes on me. JOHN hesitates a beat.   Then he is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH catches sight of JOHN riding across the heath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Davinier is leaving very early today! DIDO moves to the window. Her POV: JOHN on horseback as h disappears over the brow. ELIZABETH, LADIES MANSFIELD and MARY watch as LORD MANSFIELD storms past the doorway.- all is not well, they can tell. LORD MANSFIELD's gaze locks with DIDO through the doorway he falters, moves on. OFF DIDO's realisation - JOHN is not coming back .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON hooves - the Mansfield carriage is on the move t London. The familiar lush horizon provides the backdrop. ON the luggage-laden carriage - the girls whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I may see Mr James in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH whispers to DIDO, completely matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could fall in love with such a man, Dido.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love? The two girls are startled. LADY MARY smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bette, you could feel no such sentiment for you should either end poor or... broken hearted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage rounds a corner, weaves through the bustle o markets, peasants, guided by HARRY, the MANSFIELD driver. ON DIDO's face, staring from the moving carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloomsbury Square opens before us. As the carriage halts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you quietly relieved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relieved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you shan't be at the caprice of some silly Sir and his fortune! (off Dido's silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of us haven't the choice! Not a chance of inheritance if we have brothers and forbidden from any activity that allows us to support ourselves. ELIZABETH sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (c'est la vie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are but their property. OFF DIDO, affected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIBBY, the housekeeper and THOMAS, the butler stand on ceremony. Maids help the Mansfield ladies as they disrobe ON DIDO as her gaze falls on MABEL (20), a black maid helping ELIZABETH with her hat. A beat as DIDO stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light the fires for dinner, will you, Thomas. ON MABEL as she catches DIDO'S stare, forcing DIDO to ave her gaze quickly, turning her back to distance herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soft light of oil lamps. DIDO, in night-clothes, drags a brush through tight ringlets. She stops, observes, a moment as ELIZABETH runs comb through her own silken hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are so beautiful, Bette. I hope your match is the most wonderful of all gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ELIZABETH wide eyed, then moved as her eyes brim. A tentative knock and MABEL enters - DIDO becomes tense. MABEL speaks gently - strong Welsh accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some bed socks for you, Miss Murray, Miss Lindsay. It's not as warm as we hoped tonight She hands a pair each to the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mabel...How kind. MABEL pauses as DIDO struggles with her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you with that, Miss Lindsay? ON DIDO, self-conscious under MABEL'S stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel, I am fine - thank you! She struggles once again, wrenching the brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must start from the ends, miss. DIDO stares at her - a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candle lit faces... DIDO's reflection in the mirror - her hair separated into four sections. In the reflection BG, ELIZABETH sits serenely watching MABEL brushing through each section from ends to roots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Mam taught me, see? DIDO stares at her a moment, some kind of pain resonates her eyes as her face softens and she begins to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four MANSFIELD ladies step from the carriage. Before them, a huge Georgian home. All four take it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me you will change that vulgar teal paint, if you ever become lady of this home. It is positively wanting, Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sophisticated landscape, very much in keeping with LADY ASHFORD'S sense of style. A maid steps out - LADY MANSFIELD follows with the four Mansfield women. ELIZABETH beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Mansfield, LADY MARY and their nieces, Madam. LADY ASHFORD moves towards them, face bright with ambitio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Ashford. The girls curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the gentlemen? Mr James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, of course. Very little could have prevented him, knowing that Miss Murray would visit today. ELIZABETH could burst. She looks up to see JAMES and OLIVER approach from the North side of the gardens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies sip drinks as LORD ASHFORD appears from the house, a man with presence (50s) cultivated and astute. He moves to OLIVER, observing DIDO, under a nearby tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Mansfield's infamous Mulatto. No wonder our `Lord Chief Justice knows not whether he is coming or going! Not your usual game, Oliver. OLIVER examines his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can not know your thoughts unless you offer them to her. He moves off, leaving OLIVER pensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD ASHFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies Mansfield! As sweet on the eye as the freshest flowers in bloom.... (off Lady M's laughter) What is in those glasses? ON OLIVER as he moves to the pond. In the BG... LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grenadine syrup...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And port!! LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which has gone to my head already! ELIZABETH is knelt at the pond's edge with JAMES - a pape boat floats on the water, toppling over to a unanimous cr OLIVER watches as DIDO approaches. His eyes light up. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Dido look - Mr James has made me a boat and it has capsized. JAMES stretches a branch into the lake to rescue the boat DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a dreadful shame. OLIVER collects paper from the grass. CLOSE on his hands he folds it into a boat under DIDO'S nose. OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to DIDO, earnest) For you. She smiles, can't help being charmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He places it in the water, stands and examines DIDO. From afar, LADY MANSFIELD watches. OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay, would you do me the honour of taking some air with me, some time? DIDO is dumbstruck - what to say? JAMES is halted. JAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you care what people will say

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO is jolted by the antangonism in JAMES' tone - ELIZABETH too - it pierces her and she speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that to mean Mr James? What should anyone say?! JAMES hesitates, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That he should compromise a lady's reputation by stepping out with her - scarcely having made her acquaintance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you are a great deal too anxious, brother. We should merely take a turn around Vauxhall. DIDO observes JAMES - His protestation is bitter. She traces OLIVER'S features, warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be delighted, Mr Oliver! Most delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the move through London streets. LADIES MANSFIELD and MARY sit quietly. ELIZABETH whispers to DIDO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you really to defy Papaa? DIDO says nothing, turns to stare out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VAUXHALL PLEASURE GARDENS. DUSK/NIGHT.11
dialogues.text: Teaming with parasols, fountains, and hidden pathways. 61.1: JAMES and ELIZABETH stroll, followed by DIDO and OLIVER, then, LADIES MANSFIELD, MARY, and ASHFORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re. Dido with Oliver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not at ease with this. Lord Mansfield would be most aggrieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh it can do no harm. This is simply two families, enjoying a day together. LADY MANSFIELD takes an unhappy breath, burdened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY ASHFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though surely...IF a desirable match were a ... certain... possibility your dear husband could have no objections, could he? LADY MANSFIELD, turns slowly to regard LADY ASHFORD, aroused by the insinuation and alarmed at the same time. She looks back to DIDO and OLIVER, wide eyed. OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I did not think I would ever find a lady who was not to be conquered or ignored...Until you. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah now how do I know this is not just another tactic in your battle to conquer? He stops, takes her hand and places it on in his chest. OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See how my heart beats. She lets her hand rest a moment. OLIVER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am utterly taken with you, Miss Lindsay. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite...such pronounced protestations from your brother? OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cannot overlook your mother's origins, as I do. Foolish. Why should anyone even pay her regard when your better half has equipped you so well with loveliness and privilege. Dido is stung. OLIVER shrugs, oblivious. The sound of Han filters from a nearby concert. DIDO tries hard to recover DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a lovely sound. He smiles at her, studies her...mischievous... OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are unrelentingly cultured. Come, let's find it! He takes her waist spinning her round with him into anoth pathway, disappearing from the others, giggling as they g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People will think she has no family! LADY ASHFORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People will think they are courting! LADY MANSFIELD and LADY MARY exchange a look. LADY MARY i somehow softened - her eyes appeal to LADY MANSFIELD... LADY MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her enjoy his society. LADY MANSFIELD is effected - reads MARY'S emotion. 61.2: An open pavilion with classical concert. ON OLIVER and DIDO watching. OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might only have dreamed of these moments, at one time. DIDO smiles - allows herself to be flattered. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? You are much of the conqueror Mr Oliver. He chuckles, brings his hand up to brush her cheek, gentl She smiles just as her eyes fall on the back of a gentlem head, shoulders - his movement somehow familiar. The sight roots her, uncertain of what she sees. And then he turns to address another, and his profile becomes clea It is JOHN DAVINIER. In that moment, he flicks his head round and his gaze fal on her - a beat between them then his eyes fall on OLIVER JOHN excuses himself from others and makes his way across JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flushed) Mr Davinier. How...how nice to see you. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, Miss Lindsay. He looks to OLIVER. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me - Mr Ashford, may I present to you...Mr Davinier. (She smiles awkward) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the son of our Vicar at Hampstead, and was..well, almost father's pupil... OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clergyman! (an `off' smile) Good day, to you...sir. OLIVER bows, manfully, asserting his greater status. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. (beat) My regards to your family, Miss Lindsay. Unexpected hope fills her. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth and Mamaa are here... in fact. DIDO watches as JOHN nods politely and moves off, returni to his company - male and all of a similar type to him. ON OLIVER, as he takes in JOHN'S effect on DIDO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61.3. The spit and bang of spectacular fireworks. OLIVER stands engrossed as the sky lights up. DIDO looks up at him. She wavers. Then...slowly she backs away from the cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61.4 DIDO walks quickly - follows the sound of the concer to find her way back to JOHN. Her POV: JOHN listening diligently to the music. He doubl takes at the sight of her hovering at the edge of the concert. He stands alarmed, negotiates his way to her. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismayed) Miss Lindsay, you are alone!! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not have the chance to see you before you left...Mr Davinier ...to convey my apologies. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apologies...? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pupilage. Father would never have ended it...you...you never would have had to leave Kenwood were it not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes soften as he looks at her... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would make mine a living hell, were he to know of us speaking. DIDO tugs him into a quiet lane, away from the concert an promenading. Hardly a breath and BAM!! She is slammed against a walled maze, suddenly!! JOHN pressed against her tightly! Confused, her gaze darts around her, finds LADY MANSFIELD and LADY ASHFORD ambling past along a cross path, oblivio DIDO freezes - held tightly against JOHN. She stares panicked into his eyes and he into hers. 61.5:CUTAWAY So they do not see ELIZABETH as she strolls with JAMES - Her gaze falling on JOHN and DIDO, instantly ELIZABETH is stunned!!!! But doesn't falter. 61.4 CONT'D: As DIDO and JOHN look back - nothing but anonymous strangers, leaving them none the wiser to being discovered. JOHN pulls away, embarrassed... JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. She nods, equally bashful. They regard each other. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here in London Mr Davinier? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am under a third cousin - a solicitor, here. Nothing more than petty disputes between unsavoury landlords and debauched tenants, but I cannot discount it. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not what you wished for. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't given up on The Inns. Nothing worth having in life comes easily. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flushed) Where are my manners? I trust the future Mrs Davinier is well. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well...thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO is unexpectedly struck - recovers herself. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have tried to keep up - with the Zong. These past weeks. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agitated) Tis pitiful! Such inability to simply know what value to put on another's life. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) What price, a worthless Negro. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) You utterly misunderstand me. I am saying that no man may have the value of that of cargo!!! Human beings cannot be priced, since we are priceless!! Freemen and slaves alike! Her eyes begin to sting at the `integrity' in his words. JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthused) I am with others here. We are all students in law - applying pressure on the insurance companies to refuse from here on to insure slaves on any ship. A simple clause. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that would require a change of law. I know nothing but... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A change in law - something the insurance companies can lobby for IF they can be persuaded to band together. (softly,) We may only be students, but...change is most always precipitated by the young. (shrugs - poignant) Someone has to have the courage. How can we expect to be civilised if we live in a barbaric world. His words wind her as JOHN shakes his head, frustrated. S takes him in - he is so very handsome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the utter injustice...the industrial slaughter of so many. DIDO stares at him earnestly. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
