dialogues.text: No. It is more than that. It's the shame of a law that would uphold a financial transaction upon that atrocity. She is scathing and accepting all at once, affecting him. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is indeed the truth. Their eyes are locked. An intimate beat that perturbs her DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never heard anyone speak like you. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor I, you, Miss Lindsay. He is emotional, it perturbs him too, now. JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must return. They will be anxious. Should I follow to see you safely. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we cannot risk it. He nods - studies her.... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good bye, Miss Lindsay. (he pauses) I suspect, we will never see each other again. The thought strikes DIDO, uneasily. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good bye, Mr Davinier. She turns, preparing herself. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay?!! (tentative) We...commune at the Coaching Inn - Kentish Town...most evenings..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trails off awkwardly. She falters. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. A beat as they regard each other - then she moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61.6: The whirl of the pleasure gardens...DIDO alone - searching hard for OLIVER or the others. Her pace quicken a hand comes down on her shoulder, taking her breath away OLIVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not dare return to Lady Mansfield without you. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) I..I am terribly sorry. I thought I saw the others, I went after them....and found myself lost. OLIVER studies her - she is so nervous...what is she hiding? A moment - then his eyes become forgiving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61.7 ON LADIES MANSFIELD, MARY, ASHFORD, seated on a benc LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost dark! LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, here are James and Miss Murray. ELIZABETH and JAMES approach, sit on the bench opposite. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do hope you know how well I think of you. JAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I do you. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I hope, Sir, you plan to honour your attentions...as not to would leave me looking... quite foolish. JAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I should not call myself a gentleman! Satisfaction washes over her. As DIDO and OLIVER appear, MANSFIELD lets our a cry of relief, goes to say something LADY ASHFORD lays a finger across LADY MANSFIELD's lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say nothing! This has all been for the good of the future, I assure you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 61.8: The two couples and ladies stroll back to the carri LADY ASHFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is a determined spirit. LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is. They stare at the couple ahead. LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She will need a gentleman who can temper her. Quite a task. She fixes on LADY MANSFIELD, lets her eyes do the talking LADY MANSFIELD exchanges a look with LADY MARY. LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lady Ashford) Do I sense that an address is finally to be made? LADY ASHFORD goes carefully... LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is an exquisite girl... (with relish) And...since there is no male heir and...it will therefore fall upon Elizabeth and her husband to eventually inherit all of Kenwood and its lands... Colour drains from LADY MANSFIELD. LADY MARY closes her eyes, dismayed. LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Ashford, may I... LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I realise there will be no end of worthy addresses to consider. ON LADY MANSFIELD as she too closes her eyes at the strai LADY ASHFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear? Lady Mansfield, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penniless?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without an inch of property, or shilling to her name! OLIVER chuckles. LADY ASHFORD rests her hand on JAMES' kn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your situation can attract so much better, James. She brings nothing but name. A real lady is blessed with SO much more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear that, James? A lady's good breeding alone will not do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Oliver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother needs a wife who will bring him further land! LOTS!... if he is ever to exert more political influence than your father has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what of her own father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Seventh Viscount Stormont is a scoundrel. Ensconced in Vienna with the girl's vicious step-mamaa and his new offspring - who I am told is to inherit EVERYTHING. She shakes her head, stares through the carriage window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must say, pen-ni-less! Thankfully her cousin is not. It is true that on each occasion I lay eyes upon that girl, she becomes more beautiful. OLIVER shifts, perturbed - DIDO, indeed, on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has the colouring of a farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, we do not talk about that, any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this really the very best you aspire to, Oliver? To introduce some woman of obscure birth into the family lineage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James - you are my first boy - blessed by law to inherit your father's wealth. Be sympathetic to your brother. Like the unfortunate Miss Murray - a good family name and empty pockets will only get him so far!! OLIVER closes his eyes, privately humiliated.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BLOOMSBURY SQ. DRAWING ROOM
dialogues.text: LADY MANSFIELD looks up from her embroidery - SOUNDS of a carriage rounding into the square. At the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens, Lord Mansfield has arrived a day early! LADY MARY moves quickly to look down on the street. Her POV: below, LORD MANSFIELD'S carriage outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel! Freshen the flowers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trunk hits the flagstone. A FOOTMAN enters with another

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautifully laid out breakfast - A spray of purple lavender, silver and porcelain. MABEL smiles privately at DIDO as she lays some bread on the table. DIDO watches her leave. DIDO looks to the newly arrived LORD MANSFIELD, as he sit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facetious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mabel a slave? LADY MANSFIELD almost chokes on her porridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is-Mabel-a-slave! LORD MANSFIELD swallows hard, his jaw tightens. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is free and under our protection. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (twice as facetious) O! Like me! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly, Dido! LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And paid a very respectable wage. DIDO takes a mouthful of breakfast, goads her father furt DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is the fraud appeal Papaa? LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fraud? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marine insurance. It is a Fraud case, is it not? LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would depend on to whom you may speak. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To cull your `cargo'? To do it solely to claim insurance because it was too diseased to achieve a good price at market? If not fraud, then what? LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you speak on my behalf, Dido? LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh will you please stop! She slams down her napkin. LADY MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a vulgar subject to be discussing at breakfast DIDO and LORD MANSFIELD are locked in a stand-off. A bitter silence. LADY MARY ventures to change the subjec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I learned yesterday that Mr Davinier is in town. DIDO stiffens. ELIZABETH stares across at her, privately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes sense. Dido is beginning to sound very much like him. DIDO has lost her appetite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. She gets up and is gone. 66   INT. LORD MANSFIELD'S LONDON CHAMBERS. HALLWAYS DAY. LORD MANSFIELD moves through hallways, robed, wigged, his full authority apparent. LORD ASHFORD walks beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had the pleasure of laying eyes on your adopted girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facetious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have raised a lovely young lady...And, though I understand she is kept under interesting rules, She raises questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spit it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her introduction to society comes at a key time in the insurance appeal. Parliament is nervous that your `family situation' will colour your judgement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will neither be pressured from the inside - or the outside. LORD ASHFORD comes to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the highest judge in the land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD ASHFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In you, they see a man who is of the persuasion and position to bring down the major trade of our time and the commercial health of this country. Some will say, next to our king, you are the most powerful man in England. And the same will ask how you, our Chief Justice can be fair? LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? RULES are in place to dictate how we live - were that not the case, I would not have had the mandate to give shelter to my nephew's child. He struggles with his emotion. LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is his blood - MINE! And rightfully had entitlement to grow up on the family estate. (aggrieved) The parliamentarians may challenge me - let them! I can tell you all, if the law supports the Zong's slave owners as strongly as Murray blood runs through Dido Belle's veins - make no mistake - the insurers will be forced to pay up! LORD ASHFORD is affected. He regards LORD MANSFIELD. LORD ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I believe you. He raises an eyebrow. Then... LORD ASHFORD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have reason to speak with you on another matter. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? LORD ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentative) I have a wish to seal the bond between the Ashford and Mansfield names. It would, however, require some relaxing of your most stringent rules, I must add! LORD MANSFIELD comes to a halt again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD steps into the room. LADY MANSFIELD turns from the window. They lock gaze in a grave moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have had reason to speak with Lord Ashford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I to Lady Ashford. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we in agreement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are. (long beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You once asked me, who would look after her when we are gone. Money is no substitute for a man's protection. I cannot deny her a match so suitable. LADY MANSFIELD nods, satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls are embroidering with LADY MARY. MABEL enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever did happen in the end, Aunt Mary? With your gentleman friend. LADY MARY looks up surprised DIDO studies her curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never married. Cousin Marjorie wrote me last year, that he had died after a long illness. She looks down and continues to sew. DIDO fights tears, unexpectedly affected. ELIZABETH takes her Aunt's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Aunt Mary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me. Mr Ashford is here for you, miss. DIDO and ELIZABETH look back at her, then at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which Mr Ashford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O excuse me! Mr Oliver, for you, Miss Lindsay. LADY MARY takes it all in, with a special interest. 69   INT. BLOOMSBURY SQ. GROUND FL.CORRIDOR/DRAWING ROOM. As DIDO enters, OLIVER stands with LADY MANSFIELD, both fixed on her. LADY MANSFIELD takes DIDO'S hand, gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need worry about nothing. Your Papaa has been dealt with. She disappears, leaving DIDO lost. A nervous silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss Lindsay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Oliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do hope my reason for being here will bring you as much happiness as it brings me. DIDO swallows hard. In the CORRIDORS - LADIES MANSFIELD and MARY listen throu a crack in the doorway. In the DRAWING ROOM - OLIVER moves closer to DIDO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think...well, I know...that we make a rather good match. (he pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father has purchased me a commission in the navy - as colonel - Is that not the rank your blood father first purchased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Indeed it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I feel my career is now set. All that remains... A long beat. OLIVER gathers his courage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can not offer you a title, Miss Lindsay..for the next `Lady Ashford'...well that title must fall to my brother's wife... (huge,nervous breath) What I am trying to say is, I can without doubt, offer you ALL that is due to `Mrs Oliver Ashford' and...and I trust that this would be acceptable to you. (he hesitates) Since...it would very much be my privilege...my honour, if you would agree to become my wife. He takes something from his top pocket. DIDO looks down, finds a large black sapphire glistening in his fingers... In the CORRIDORS. LADY MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot see...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooosh! On the stairs, ELIZABETH slows, as she approaches. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, Elizabeth! In the DRAWING ROOM - DIDO is still staring at the ring. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord, Mr Oliver! Your ...your wife? Mrs Ashford?! She repeats the title and conflict washes over her.

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: (swallows hard.) ...I cannot... (she pauses) I cannot...think of anything ...more wonderful! He stares at her.    She looks back at him, stunned. In the CORRIDORS.... LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overjoyed) She has agreed! O...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed? LADY MANSFIELD throws open the doors, elated.

dialogues.speaker: O...
dialogues.text: OLIVER stands, his chest bursting with pride. DIDO shell- shocked, holds up her ring finger - the sapphire flashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamaa, we are engaged! LADY MANSFIELD eyes fill. She touches DIDO'S face softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a good thing, is it not, Mamaa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers, poignant)                                *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are my heart - from the                             * moment I saw you. I only want you                       * to be happy.                                            * LADY MARY wipes a tear, discreet as ELIZABETH stands, roo 70   INT. BLOOMSBURY SQ. DIDO & ELIZABETH'S BEDROOM. Darkness.   ELIZABETH whispers softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido...was there any message for me? DIDO hesitates a moment - then whispers back just as soft

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Bette (beat) But..I am sure it                      * won't be long. ELIZABETH thinks a moment - Then musters a smile for DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it feel like Dido? To be engaged? DIDO is struck.     She falters, privately, as she thinks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect, Bette - pefect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. DIDO awake as ELIZABETH sleeps. DIDO slips from be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits alone at the window, silhouetted by moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Informal breakfast. LORD MANSFIELD approaches in a bustle of importance and sits. LADY MANSFIELD and LADY MARY exchange tense glances. DIDO considers whether to speak, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa. He looks up.   DIDO is sincere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. LORD MANSFIELD nods. Tension is relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are to make many calls today, Elizabeth. Acquainting oneself with the most eligible gentleman is not light business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we not wait a day or two - for Mr James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth - some advice.     Wait for no man, dear! She picks up her pamphlet. On the back, a headline reads: Student Politics Puts Rise to Pain of Insurers.   ON DIDO as she double takes. ELIZABETH follows DIDO'S gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you join us, Dido? (no response)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido? She is absorbed in the headline. Absolutely rooted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I..I am terribly light headed this morning, Mamaa. I should like to take rest if it would not displease you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear! Unwell? And just as we are to announce your news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido stands at the top of the sweeping stairs, watches as ELIZABETH and LADY MANSFIELD fuss, before disappearing to their carriage... On DIDO as she thinks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO quickly makes her way down - a hooded figure, carryi two scrolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry is asleep at his seat.   DIDO reaches up on tiptoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry! Harry! He wakes with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, I need your help. I need you to take me somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall not be alone, I shall be with you. (off Harry, reticent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please - Harry. If you don't take me, I shall be forced to go alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunset. ON HARRY negotiating the carriage through bedlam his anonymous passenger inside, curtains closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO steadies herself with a deep breath as the carriage comes to a halt. She draws the curtain back slightly. Her POV: The exterior of the Coaching Inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV, negotiating the dark crowded inn - An intellectual brood, mostly men in their own little cliques, discussing the woes of the world and nursing malt beer. We find JOHN - in amongst his group, an intense discussio in full swing, a table laid with pamphlets, papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge figure approaches. JOHN stops mid speech, stares u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier? JOHN takes a moment - he's alarmed, but somehow, this man is familiar - then...uncertain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO waits nervously. Suddenly, her breath is taken away as the carriage door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay! As he climbs inside.    He is stunned, flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier. It makes him breathless just to see her there. A beat pas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't expect...! Are you to come inside?...Are...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...It would be dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling foolish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mr Davinier...I am so proud of you. I am so proud of what you are doing and...achieving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We've achieved little.... She lifts his face to hers, earnestly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least thirty per cent of insurers are with you! It is a start. It is a real start. They are staring straight into each other's eyes. She pul her hands away, self consciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something to show you. She collects the two scrolls beside her, each ribbon tied She hands one to JOHN, smoothing the other on her lap. DIDO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is said all of the ship's papers have been `lost'... but...here...I found these in Papaa's library. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa's notes on the ship's log. It seems the First Mate has come forward with it - one Mr Stubbs. I could not find the log itself, but look at Papaa's markings - See the map positions - From December 29th, Captain Collingwood and his men directed the ship past no less than eight ports where, you see.... (she points to map) ...there was every opportunity to stop and replenish the ship's water supplies. JOHN studies the log and map together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they did not! They either ignored the possibilities, or they were never in need. JOHN'S gaze darts from notes to the map, absorbed. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This...This is remarkable. He looks up from the papers.   DIDO is still tentative. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? Perhaps if you made these facts known, Mr Davinier JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this places you in an impossible position with Lord Mansfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the alternative? His face searches hers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk with me, Miss Lindsay. The back of the Inn has the canals, (he laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody but blind drunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful light fills the room. MABEL distributes candl as LORD MANSFIELD enters - informal and without wig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is everybody, Mabel? The carriages are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Mansfield and Miss Murray are out calling, your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Dido also?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erm...I believe so. LORD MANSFIELD stares at her irritated - peculiar girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well is she, or isn't she? MABEL wavers, attempts to sound convincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She is, M'lord. LORD MANSFIELD watches as she stiffly moves from the room He goes to ask something more...then thinks better of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is almost down.   A hooded DIDO walks beside JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa would rather I see no ill, as though by ignoring it, it some how escapes me - perhaps by position but not...not by blood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conciliatory) The fault was never with you. He stops a beat as he catches her gaze on a painted metal sign swinging from the back of an inn. It shows a gent, hat in hand, his black servant bowing behind him. JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsure) Miss Lindsay? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as in life, we are no better in paintings... He follows her gaze back to the image and realisation hit JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid? JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be painted - to be painted beside Miss Murray (off her discomfort ) And I ridiculed you. (swallows hard) I feel ashamed. She looks back at him earnestly... DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not feel ashamed. (she observes him) Elizabeth said something when we arrived in London. She said: (recounting) we are but their property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen's. We women are but the property of gentlemen. That is the way it is, in law and in life, is it not? JOHN nods, uneasily.    DIDO thinks aloud. DIDO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it came into my head that I have been blessed with freedom twice over? As a negro and as a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you have, yes! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or have I? ((her mind ticks over) Must not a lady marry, even if she is financially secure? For who is she, without a husband of consequence? (she ponders) It seems silly - like a free negro who begs for a master! JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless she marries her equal. Her true equal - A man who respects her. DIDO is silent. She steals a glance at him. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember my Papaa's eyes. They were kind, gentle... a little like yours... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) I mean...in colour. Grey. (long beat) He showed me much love, though I knew him only a few hours. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is terribly moving. (off her reaction) What of your mother? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a ghost in my life - present in my reflection, in each scowl I receive, yet I know very little of her than the colour she has given me. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moved) Then at the least, you know she was beautiful. They come to a halt. DIDO's eyes begin to sting. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had never felt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had? They observe each other a moment. Will they kiss? Dido pulls back, nervous of the intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am to marry, shortly - Mr Ashford. JOHN falters but tries to recover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! She begins to walk again - composing herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is amiable and of good family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it...what you want? She stops.    The question strikes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alternative is to replace Lady Mary in her responsibilities at Kenwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she is a spinster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa did not trust I could achieve a match that might raise my rank - or even equal it. JOHN searches her, then gently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You...are above reducing yourself for the sake of rank. She stares at him, frozen - his words bury somewhere deep She studies him, harder. He moves towards her, letting hi breath settle on her face. They are both deadly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pray he would marry you without a penny to your name - for that is a man who will truly treasure you! DIDO searches him. He takes her hand, brings it to his li kissing it gently sending a shiver through her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will take you back to your coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF DIDO reeling, from the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO enters the house, terrified, as she takes off her hood. MABEL passes in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anyone home, Mabel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Mansfield. (Dido's heart plummets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said you were out with Lady Mansfield and Miss Murray OFF DIDO'S relief/gratitude. She makes her way up the stairs quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH falls back onto her bed, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Urghhh! What if I shall never find someone so...so incomparably suitable...and wealthy?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if he is suitable but you do not feel...`yourself' with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Dido! He understood me. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And whenever...whenever... he looked at me...I somehow felt better in this world... ELIZABETH'S voice trails. Her words force DIDO to turn aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am convinced his affections were growing...and I feel certain of my own love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Bette, stop it! It is NOT love!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido! You stop it, won't you? You know no more of love than I myself, do you?! (deliberately pointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you Dido?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds her to account - willing DIDO to open up to her DIDO stares daunted, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Beat. ELIZABETH swallows hard, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what better right do you have to name what I am feeling than me? OFF DIDO affected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decandence personified...a beautiful picnic, shaded by tr Punts float up and down lackadaisically. ELIZABETH listen LADY MANSFIELD interrogates a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How charming. Is that not charming, Elizabeth? And tell me, are you an only son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have six brothers, madam. LADY MANSFIELD'S smile stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIX! Goodness!...all..? He knows where this is going...defeated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...all older, madam, yes. Her smile falls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that not a most fascinating display? He turns to look at the bush of flowers behind him. When he turns back, LADY MANSFIELD and ELIZABETH are gone. ON BARONESS VERNON (50s) who passes on a punt, utterly captivated as she waves. Her eyes are on DIDO, stunningly beautiful in fuchsia, beside OLIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh how dreadfully wonderful Lady M. Your girl is a picture...an utter picture! With her...'intended'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, Baroness Vernon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARONESS VERNON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re. ELIZABETH) AND I see the other does not give up...so terribly endearing! She stares across at ELIZABETH - ON BETTE'S contempt. BARONESS VERNON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now has she met Mr Willoughby... She points to a gent and leans into the bankside... BARONESS VERNON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very eligible widower - Three thousand yearly and no heir...yet! Her punt moves off as she waves gauche to two gentlemen passing in another. BARONESS VERNON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Francis, Mr Smith...!!! You must meet the Mansfield girl! (She mouths) Still available!! ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious) Mamaa, Mr Vaughan approaches. A slender, dapper gent moves towards us on the river bank LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I have checked and he has no London home, but I have good information he achieves an income no less than four thousand a year! ELIZABETH's mouth falls open.... MR VAUGHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Murray. Lady Mansfield. ELIZABETH curtseys. MR VAUGHAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust your stay in London is proving pleasant, Miss Murray. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnest) Oh most certainly. MR VAUGHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Murray, I wonder, if you might permit me to call upon you at home, sometime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! She looks to her mother, stunned, his gaze follows... MR VAUGHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her Ladyship's permission? LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall make arrangements. ON DIDO, as OLIVER chats to others. She moves past as... LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pity Lady Mansfield and I could not do business on James and Miss Murray. LADY MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A greater pity you rejected her. LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us not dwell on the unfortunate. Oliver and Miss Lindsay are a blissful match. Tell me, when exactly does she receive her inheritance? As DIDO observes her reflection in waters - easy laughter floats by - a group of gentleman josh. A figure beside her turns - icy blue stare takes her in a she meets his gaze and finds herself staring into the eye of JAMES ASHFORD. JAMES ASHFORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay. Not Husband hunting, are we? (off Dido's disdain) Good Lord, I forgot - you have ensnared my brother. Now is he to share his dining room with you, as well as his bed?? His words bury deep and painful. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr James, your manners are as poor as your brother's finances. JAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are foolish enough to marry him. I on the other have no better use for your impoverished cousin!...(beat)...Though she does make for rather amusing sport!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows his gaze through trees to ELIZABETH breathing in the scent of the azaleas beside MR VAUGHAN. The joshin gentlemen trickle away leaving only DIDO and JAMES. She goes to move off. JAMES grabs her arm, spitefully. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is painful, sir. JAMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you never been manhandled? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not in my repertoire to keep company with beasts. He regards her - her disdain reflected in his eyes. His free hand comes up, fingers rest on her lips, then spread as he crushes her beauty in his hand. Her eyes fill as he brings her close. So close. She is afraid, angry. She struggles desperately, spirited, both arousing and alarming him. As she tears herself from him DIDO (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you? HOW DARE YOU! He stares at her - takes her in, calmly. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With ease. DIDO wavers nauseous with contempt.   JAMES moves off. watches, incensed, humiliated. ELIZABETH strolls with MR VAUGHAN, as JAMES passes OLIVER he whispers to his brother. JAMES (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will destroy us. You will destroy the entire order of our family. Nearby, DIDO emerges from the trees... LADY ASHFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver has been searching for you! LADY MANSFIELD notes DIDO'S odd demeanour, LADY MARY too. Her eyes dart suspiciously to JAMES as he approaches. LADY MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you unwell, my dear? DIDO's affected eyes come up to meet her mother's. She go to answer...interrupted as...ELIZABETH gasps overwhelmed. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!..Mr James!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distressed DIDO follows her gaze back to JAMES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Ashford, you had not mentioned Mr James was to attend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprisingly. LADY ASHFORD closes her eyes,livid. VAUGHAN stands usurpe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies. (off Dido's reaction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Murray. He kisses ELIZABETH'S hand oh so gently, for DIDO'S benefit. LADY MANSFIELD's heart sinks. OFF DIDO, turbulent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO sitting at the window, a sad figure. A MONTAGE OF SHOTS OVER DIFFERENT DAYS FOLLOWS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A busy area - As workers traipse up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had never imagined myself to be married. But my aunt is determined. It is true that if one were to count, I had not even been acquainted with Miss Beresford on three occasions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she not terribly disappointed that you will not return to Hampstead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ironic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: my Aunt? They begin to laugh...it's good to see DIDO laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt Miss Beresford has anymore wish to marry me than I her. I should rather make a nuisance of myself alone in London, than in an unwanted marriage in Hampstead... Their laughter carries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NEW DAY...bustling, behind the canal. DIDO and JOHN str

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you a curious child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Completely. Elizabeth, always asked the questions for me... then took blame for the impropriety when in fact she was protecting me! Dear, dear Bette. Laughter... POV: a pamphlet lies on the ground. It reads: LORD MANSFIELD, THE ZONG AND THE DEATH OF ENGLAND'S TRADE. JOHN watches as DIDO takes in the headline...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER DAY....ON JOHN and DIDO as they meander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I find myself unable to sleep. Papaa is to finally speak in a few days and...well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quite extraordinary ...but I fear...I fear despite persuasive argument...your Papaa has not been moved. (despondent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not certain he is ready to go against the traders - they are some of the most powerful in these Isles - theirs are the finances that hold up England, after all. The enemies of any man who stood against the trade would be vicious. DIDO stops, turns JOHN to face her.   She is intense...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet if he does...stand up...IF he speaks the words and condemns the trade...The Lord Chief Justice of England...it may be impossible for the slave laws of England and its colonies to remain absolute. Is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That...that is a fact. A tear spills. As JOHN'S hand come up to wipe it away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO steps into the house, hooded, tip-toeing to the stai LORD MANSFIELD steps from the shadows, watches quietly, a she creeps up the stairs, silently. He thinks a moment - then hears the horses neighing out front. He moves to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV - HARRY disembarks, alarmed as he sees LORD MANSFIELD gaze on him. An ominous beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH at the pianoforte, raising a sweet sound. DIDO appears in the doorway, listens a moment, then moves to join ELIZABETH, using only the one hand to play. A harmony emerges, continuing to its natural end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have heard nothing from him, since Vauxhall, Dido. I was certain an announcement was to be made any day...that he meant it this time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he is not a man of his word. ELIZABETH stares at the piano keys. DIDO is pained for he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will help you find the kindest most wonderful of husbands. (off Bette's sadness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I shall ask Papaa to use a portion of my inheritance for your dowry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would do that? For me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bette, anything for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH'S eyes brim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido... She hugs DIDO tight. ELIZABETH (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been of the mind these last few days...that it is my little means that has delayed James in making his approach. DIDO regards her, sadly - tentative as she ventures... DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you may be right. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I cannot thank you enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bette...? ELIZABETH stands, brighter, smoothing her clothes. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will ask Papaa to write immediately to Lady Ashford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? DIDO gets up too, now. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Ashford is not kind. He is not a man to give your life or dowry to. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then your gift comes with conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am trying...trying to make you see. He is not... appropriate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appropriate? The brother of the man you are to marry is not `appropriate' for me? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does not desire you, Bette! At least, even if he does, you would regret such a mistake. (off Bette's silence) He...he laid his hands on me, Bette - in the most un-gentlemanly fashion. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should you say such a thing? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurt me. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a liar! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why...why would I lie to you? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know - but do you not see? Have you never been able to see? He would never touch you...! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bette... ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are beneath him! A long beat. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am beneath him?? ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You...you are... DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! Tell me! What am I, Bette? She dares ELIZABETH to cross their line of sisterhood. ELIZABETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You...you are....(courage leaves her)...You are illegitimate!! DIDO is winded, but relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you never wondered why you are not permitted to eat with our guests? Dido draws breath to calm herself, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother and father never married - you are correct. But my father acknowledged me as his child. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is yours who refuses to legitimise your position, Bette - that is why you are poor! And that is why it is not me who is beneath Mr James, Bette. It is not me! ELIZABETH stings - she fights tears, before she disappear A dreadful silence. DIDO looks down at the black sapphire on her finger. A moment, then she slips it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO, alone. She studies her reflection at the dressing table. A moment. A soft breath - something in her relaxes the look on her face, just as soft as she regards herself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO hooded and cloaked, races quickly. Suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Lindsay. Are you out again? DIDO turns to MABEL, presses her fingers to her lips, appealing to her, before slipping from the house MABEL stands frozen, a porcelain jug in each hand,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As DIDO climbs into the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horse hooves trotting rhythmically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO sits patiently, her heart pounding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON HARRY'S sweating cheeks as he guides the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage as it pulls up in front of the Coaching Inn. DIDO takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As HARRY climbs from the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE: HARRY'S outline, as we follow him to the Inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO smoothing her dress. The door of the carriage opens before she can finish. She looks up - the happiest smile... It falls from her lips, as quickly as it came and she starts to tremble, at what comes towards her. The sight of LORD MANSFIELD as he climbs into the carriag ...and sits opposite her, silent - a cold stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN follows HARRY to exit the Inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage door opens - JOHN climbs in, barely taking a moment to look where he is going, and as he looks up, he too sets eyes on LORD MANSFIELD. JOHN looks back to HARRY, stunned. HARRY's gaze locks wit DIDO'S. She is hurt. He falters, closes the carriage door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa...? LORD MANSFIELD is incandescent. He shakes with rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man's ambitions include you. You will endure shame and risk your position for a man without name, who will sully yours and drag your reputation to the gutter! JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitter and humiliated) I take great offence in your summation of my character without ever even taking a moment to know me. Where is your right? LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I have EVERY right...! JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No! That you will never have! Not until you cease from judging the entire world as those above and those below and begin to see people as PEOPLE! Human beings, who think and feel no more or less than you do! LORD MANSFIELD stands arrested. JOHN'S words strike deep. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know there is a lady in Belsize who is waiting to be your wife. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I have an ambitious aunt in Belsize, who like you, assumes reputation and fortune are all that life depends on, and despises love as though it were the devil's own creation! LORD MANSFIELD's eyes narrow dangerously - rage explodes. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love? You claim love....?? He reaches for JOHN'S neck. DIDO throws herself at them. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! STOP! Papaa, you must stop! As she struggles to keep them apart. JOHN falls against the door. He shouts at the top of his voice to be heard. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...yes I love her! I love her with every breath I breathe. Silence! DIDO and LORD MANSFIELD are stunned. A painful b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go John.   You do not deserve this. JOHN'S breath is heavy, his heart pounding. He catches hi breath, almost chokes on it as he rises, moving with uncertainty from the carriage, and is gone. DIDO stares a LORD MANSFIELD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sir John Lindsay would never have behaved like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Sir John Lindsay would never behave like this because he was never HERE!...You are destroying your possibilities with the only gentleman who will consider you. (searching her, hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you want? No, perhaps it isn't! DIDO stands wavering - daunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fist comes down hard on the rosewood table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrogant...parasite! HE is filling her with worthless ideals. He wants to `make the world a better place'!... LORD MANSFIELD is puffed with fury as he paces the room. He knocks the table again, jolting LADY MANSFIELD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is laughing at us! His childish campaign simply adds to my already rampant ridicule in the gossip pamphlets and now...! As though he were some kind of...saint, immune from reproach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said something identical, once. LORD MANSFIELD stops in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you wanted to change the world! Quite some time before you entered your chambers, of course. Defiant, principled...driven. (off Lord M)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desperate to seal your position among the establishment but always a little too radical for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never broke the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you not? You simply became powerful enough to make new ones. (off his silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always felt you already loved me when I gave you my hand. Not that you said it but... something in the way you looked at me. LORD MANSFIELD'S face softens slightly, struck by his wife's words - of course he loved her! He adored her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That we were a good match - that was of no doubt...But I am not sure I could have married a gentleman without that...`thing' in his eye...without knowing - privately - that my heart stopped a moment each time he looked at me Their eyes are locked. She speaks carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is possible that even you cannot fight change, my darling... And sometimes you cannot fight it because you are a part of it. Her words resonate, shifting him into thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love her? His eyes fill. What he says next is deeply heartfelt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As though she were created of you and I...(poignant)...And that is why I simply do not want to see her diminished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like subjects of a pastel Joshua Reynolds painting, the MANSFIELD ladies are draped around the room . LADY MARY uses a dainty magnifying glass to read a pamphl as LADY MANSFIELD sips tea, ELIZABETH reads and DIDO gaze out of the window...LADY MARY reads aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The niece of the Marquess of Winchester. Mr James Ashford is to marry the niece of the Marquess of Winchester. ELIZABETH looks up, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am reading it here. She indicates the pamphlet and her heart sinks as she see ELIZABETH'S heartache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That shall render your future mother-in-law ecstatic, Dido. ELIZABETH slams her book down, gets up and storms off. DI thinks about it a beat, uncertain then goes after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ELIZABETH sobbing into DIDO'S arms. She lifts her head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare say a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why! Why do they ALWAYS do that!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, Bette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men! They leave and never come back! A painful beat, then DIDO kisses and hugs her tightly, as ELIZABETH desperately sobs some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO lies still in bed, ELIZABETH beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you with him, that day.   At the pleasure garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted you to tell me. To trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, if I had your choice, I would choose...the man I loved (off Dido, sad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I simply hope he is worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVER stands, numb. LADY ASHFORD turns to us, eyes flash

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not in the habit of requiring explanation more than TWICE! But on this occasion, you will have to forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (burdened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Ashford there is little point in repetition...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let me be clear that I have understood. Your charge - your mulatto charge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fiercely protective)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is enough! DIDO sits staring at the floor. OLIVER cuts in, aggrieved

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lady Mansfield)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it not true enough, your ladyship?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...whose unfortunate circumstances of birth, we chose to forgive - has decided she no longer wishes the match with my son - a gentleman and an officer. OLIVER stares across at DIDO. He speaks quietly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Miss Lindsay? DIDO is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (poignant and pained)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel I have any lesser need to ensure my child's wellbeing and future than you?...(beat)...Does she still have a tongue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a tongue, Madam. Though yours explains well enough why I may not marry your son...beat)... You view my circumstances as unfortunate, though I cannot claim even a portion of the misfortune of those to whom I most closely resemble. ON LADY MANSFIELD stung by the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My greatest misfortune would be to marry into a family who will carry me as their shame - as I have been required to carry my own mother. LORD MANSFIELD swallows hard.   LADY MANSFIELD's gaze fal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her apparent crime, to be born negro, and mine - to be the evidence. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I wish to deny her no more than I wish to deny myself, you will pardon me for wanting a husband who feels `forgiveness' of my bloodline is both unnecessary and without grace. ON the astonished ASHFORD faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO steps from the room, shaken...what has she just done LADY MARY approaches, intuitively hands DIDO a hankerchie

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Wide on the canal, bustling with life - the poor and working classes. - FIND JOHN sitting alone, forlorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A canvas stands hidden under hemp fabric. ZOFFANY stands beside it. LORD MANSFIELD before him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO surrounded by Summer blooms. She reads a poetry book

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ZOFFANY carefully removes the hemp - a series of actio slowly uncovering his painting. We do not see it revealed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As DIDO repeats a sentence from the book to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did I, slave, beyond my lot aspire.. The line repeats itself in her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD before the painting, shielding it from us. ON ZOFFANY as his eyes fall on the window. LORD MANSFIELD follows his gaze, to DIDO alone in the gardens, reading. POV: THROUGH THE WINDOW, as DIDO feels their gaze. She falters. Her eyes dart through the glass, beyond LORD MANSFIELD, to the canvas....The sight causes her to stand drawn to the window to see more clearly. The camera, too, draws in on the portrait, now. And as it is revealed to DIDO, so too, is it finally revealed to us It is a serenely sensitive representation of two delicate English ladies - one part black, as they stand as equals, against Kenwood's iconic gardens. CLOSE on DIDO, shaken, taking in the extraordinary image. Off both men, each as moved as she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera hovers on the painting - The image of ELIZABETH'S delicate hand laying gently on DIDO'S arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD (OOV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will hang at Kenwood. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it? LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should that surprise you? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should it not? LORD MANSFIELD says nothing, observes her, curious. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you reading? DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poetry. A gentleman named Thomas Day. He speaks of a slave who agreed to marry a free woman. A voice to people...people like my mother - who do not have one. People like the drowned slaves. He takes her point. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find yourself in such writing? The camera tracks, capturing them taking in the canvas. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that I find myself anywhere. I have no place that I may claim. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it that you want, Dido? What precisely are you searching for? I enabled every rule of heritage so that you could know exactly where you belong. Yet little appears enough for you! DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papaa, you enabled every rule, but you had to overlook just as many to raise me within good society. And what if there were not a rule Papaa? What if that rule that allowed you to take me did not exist? Would you have returned me to the slums? The air is poignant with the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are courageous. When it comes to the matters you believe in, society is inconsequential. You break EVERY rule when it matters enough. Papaa, I am the evidence. (OFF the painting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This painting...is the evidence. Her words are stark. LORD MANSFIELD follows her gaze to t painting, swallowing hard. Something in him is shifting. 116   INT. LLOYD'S OF LONDON. COFFEE HO. ROYAL EXCHANGE. The hub of the mercantile profession. This is LORD MANSFIELD'S world. It is pillared, and elegant, teaming with Lloyd's members - Insurance men, brokers, lawyers - all engaged in commerce and politics. ON LORD MANSFIELD with the LORD MAYOR. They weave past to sit with others, equally wigged - power houses of England watched by all in the room. In every corner, heated debat rages - the imminent Zong decision on everyone's lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at them - For and against at each other's throats! How on earth did the damn quakers find their way into here!..(beat)..You are a brave man, negotiating these quarters on the eve of your judgement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did not become Lord Mayor through being a coward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally you are to speak, then. If England is destroyed we shall blame you! He slaps LORD MANSFIELD's back, playfully, but is deadly serious. LORD MANSFIELD is distracted...through the bustl in the room, the SOUND of YOUNG MEN debating at a table, insurance underwriters before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But religion cannot be the only guardian of our morality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not - there is self- responsibility? LORD MANSFIELD'S POV: we make out JOHN debating intensely

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And failing that does the law not have a duty? ON LORD MANSFIELD - his own group continue in conversatio but all his attention is on JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do the bench and parliament not have a duty to uphold and create the laws, to set the precedents that progress our morality, not retard it! If not to protect us from others, then to protect us from ourselves! Laws that allow us to diminish the humanity of anybody, are not laws - they are frameworks for crime. ON LORD MANSFIELD - something going on behind the eyes. T rest of the room fades - making JOHN clear and crisp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A constitution can never be finite - surely as humanity evolves so too must its laws. And frankly I really do not care if you as an individual are without character or conscience - But a land whose laws contain neither - whose laws sanction not control the barbarous among its citizens - that is a country whose hope is lost. LORD MANSFIELD's gaze falls away, as he swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN exits Lloyd's, into the open halls of the Exchange. LORD MANSFIELD fits his tricorn (hat), preparing to leave The two men lay eyes on each other - both rooted. LORD MANSFIELD'S examines JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does it matter to you so? JOHN stares at him bewildered, at a loss for words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD walks to his carriage. JOHN races after hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'lord..! It..it is a misuse of the clause. It is not for human lives. It is for goods.. Chattel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD keeps walking. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (factual) It is for property! JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I HAVE SEEN YOUR NOTES!! If they wanted water they could have had it! ON LORD MANSFIELD'S realisation - DIDO has given the information to JOHN. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dido. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you find for the traders, you will be formalizing in law the concept of insuring `human' cargo. LORD MANSFIELD climbs into his carriage. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct!...(to his driver)...Drive! The carriage begins to move off.   JOHN walks alongside i JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then know that when you are gone, your legacy will be to have left Miss Lindsay in a world that says she may be worth more dead, than alive. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is not a slave. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the very grace of God! The words provoke LORD MANSFIELD. He stands, slamming his hand to the driver's wall. The carriage halts abruptly. JOHN stands at the carriage window, breathless. LORD MANSFIELD looks down at him furious, suddenly disarmed by the emotion in JOHN'S eyes. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not about Miss Lindsay. JOHN is confused, flustered. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is! It's about all of us. It's about everything... everything that is important!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD searches JOHN, palpably affected now. He doesn't want to show JOHN his empathy, fights it - but fo a split second it escapes in the profound silence. He recovers himself - considers his words before he speak quietly - as though from personal experience...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Davinier, the world is a devastating place. You must learn to protect your emotions if you are to prevent matters of both law..and love from devastating you. JOHN is frozen, averts his gaze. LORD MANSFIELD regards him, affected, bangs on the carriage again and is gone. OFF JOHN, shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV: looking down at the sweeping stairs and entrance hal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smooth your dress, young lady! LADY MANSFIELD pinches ELIZABETH'S cheeks. LADY MARY fuss anxiously The bell chimes. ELIZABETH'S excitement rises. steals a glance up the stairs to REVEAL DIDO surreptitiou watching. The BUTLER sweeps by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Mansfield...Miss Murray... As MR VAUGHAN enters Elizabeth descends into a curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Vaughan, how kind of you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have thought of nothing else but showing you Aunt Mary's chrysanthemums, Mr Vaughan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a pleasure, Miss Murray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too Mamaa. She drags them away, sending DIDO a final surreptitious glance that says, the coast is clear for her. As she does LADY MARY'S gaze follows - sees DIDO hiding. A beat. LADY MARY hangs back - smiles satisfied to herself, before moving off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hooded DIDO steps from the house. HARRY's heart sinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! Never again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! Then step down and allow me to take the reigns. Harry rubs his eyes, burdened. Then...far from jovial..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had I known you were to be such trouble, I'd `ave driven off before Captain Sir John Lindsay bought you to my carriage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A myriad of people flood into the court - politicians, clergy, shipping merchants, abolitionists...and insurers. DIDO steps from the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pour through the doors, we settle first on LORD ASHFORD, then, JOHN DAVINIER, pushing into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later...DIDO pushes into the court. She lays eyes JOHN, seated - forces her way past seated men, seen at earlier meetings. JOHN stands, overwhelmed as she approac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD enters - sits, flanked by two LAW LORDS. H appears profoundly focused - reserved, despite the chaos the filled room. His eyes dance across the sea of faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence in the court! DIDO's hand slides to JOHN'S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether the `jettison clause' of Marine Insurance Law may be brought to bear in this appeal. This is the question. That is, first: whether the slaves were drowned as an anticipatory act. An act to avoid the disease caused by their

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: journey, killing them once on shore, and at their destination...depriving the slave owners of any compensation. He takes in the gaze of a free black man in the gallery. LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or secondly: whether they were `jettisoned' as cargo! To save captain and crew from certain death, when the extended journey threatened shortage of drinking-water. (steely eyed) Let me be clear, loss of water on a ship constitutes a singularly dangerous affair - insurrection of thirsty and hostile slaves at its extreme - and an impossible task to share diminished water reserve, among all those living, at best. Each implies severe threat to the lives of the seamen. In such circumstances our law is transparent and equivocal - the jettisoning of enslaved cargo ...IS legal! (he spells it out) And in these circumstances, combined with unavoidable loss of water, our laws leave the ship-owners securely within their rights to make a claim ...and behoves the insurers to pay losses. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Gasps from around the room...gasps that turn into cries, including DIDO'S own. JOHN is rigid, anger rising. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship's owners chose a tight `packing fashion' to transport the slaves...A popular fashion of transportation that is known for causing death and disease. His voice is raised over the sounds of a chaotic court. LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This choice of laying the slaves tightly together is undertaken at the Captain's own risk. In the event that over packing renders an avoidable lack of drinking water on board a protracted journey, such a decision may be viewed as simple `bad management' on a (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain's part, and further, weigh as his own risk. An extended journey - one in which the destination is overshot may also be viewed as the captain's own mismanagement. The noise lowers to silence. LORD MANSFIELD settles on JO LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not legal...to discharge lives from a ship into the waters, to prevent those lives dying on land, and to facilitate insurance compensation. Whether they be the lives of horses... or human beings ...slaves or otherwise - It is not legal, neither is it right. DIDO lets out a gasp - breathless relief. LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further, the claim of shortage of water is illegitimate shown by the evidence put forward. To my mind, it is clear a fraud has been committed in claiming insurance on slaves who were...drowned solely for financial gain. He looks around the room - sees LORD ASHFORD's acceptance His eyes fall on DIDO now and here they remain. LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my opinion, that the state of slavery is so odious a position that nothing may support it. This case has displayed with searing clarity the depravity of any such nation whose choice is to practice it. You may be certain that I have laboured over my judgement and statements today and am in full understanding of all of the ramifications. Justice be done,though the heavens may fall. JOHN'S eyes brim at the realisation of those words. LORD MANSFIELD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I find in favour of the insurers and overturn the decision of the lower court. I order a retrial. Stunned confusion in the courtroom. Then, all kinds of commotion - anger, cheers amid shock. LORD MANSFIELD stan CLERK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All rise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN jumps up, desperate for eye contact through the commotion...but LORD MANSFIELD fixes ahead, moves off. DIDO stands, caught by her own breath. JOHN turns to her. She begins to sob. For the first time he pulls her close, WIDE on the court room - JOHN holding DIDO as she sobs. Through the judges' exit - a figure, in the shadows. REVE LORD MANSFIELD, taking in DIDO and JOHN, affected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN watches as DIDO races back to the carriage. ON their reaction - LORD MANSFIELD stands waiting. As DIDO and LORD MANSFIELD come before each other. Everyt in their eyes - restrained emotion over a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may not blame Mr Davinier ...My attendance today is absolutely at my own volition ...for matters which concern me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am fully aware, Dido. He fixes on JOHN. JOHN is apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'Lord...I am inspired by your decision today. We will not go backwards from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (burdened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History will judge if your optimism is warranted...(beat)... You are a man of conviction. JOHN swallows hard, emotion rising, stinging his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am trying to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then your efforts are not in vain. DIDO moves to JOHN'S side, taking his hand. LORD MANSFIELD's eyes drop to their clasped fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not changed my mind. She is to marry a gentleman. He turns and begins to move to the carriage.   JOHN stare at the ground, humiliated. DIDO is incensed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Mr Davinier is not a gentleman? Her voice rings out, furious. LORD MANSFIELD stops... LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is...indeed...Dido. (he speaks carefully) And that is why he ought to have a job befitting one. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper - defiant) My affections are with him, Papaa. I wish for nothing... nothing, if not to be his wife. She stares into LORD MANSFIELD's eyes - he takes in JOHN. LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you would Mr Davinier, I would like you to attend my chambers in the morning. There are matters I would like you to assist me with. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Lordship? LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you think it a good idea...I wish to facilitate your entry to the Inns of Court. JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentative) That is to serve my qualification to The Bar? The question LORD MANSFIELD once put to JOHN, is now answ LORD MANSFIELD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed...(humbled)...Capabilities such as yours are clearly deserving of such considerations. JOHN breathes heavily, also humbled, as his tears surface JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I..I think it a very good idea, sir. LORD MANSFIELD nods, then finally moves off.    JOHN can' take it in. DIDO is breathless, eyes brim... JOHN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can it be true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. He sees what I see. His words were as clear as... JOHN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! That your feelings for me are so? That you would be my wife..? (off her reaction, ) Because, I cannot conceive of a life without you...and if...if such were all that were before me, Miss Lindsay, then my heart would never beat the same again. DIDO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not. It is not all that is before you Mr Davinier... (begins sobbing) I love you...for all that you are, and with all..all that I am. He breaks down now too, wiping her tears before kissing h through his own sobs. Then tears turn to laughter. We draw back on the couple - two fragile figures, amid th bustle of London town. ON the MANSFIELD crest as LORD MANSFIELD'S carriage moves off, a solitary figure inside, staring straight ahead.
